into His Paradise. May Allah make us among those who listen to speech and follow the best of it. Know that the reference of the innovations referred to returns to several matters:
First: Weak Hadiths which are not permissible to use as proof nor attribute to the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). Such things are not permissible to act upon according to us, as I clarified in the introduction of "Sifat Salat al-Nabi (Description of the Prophet's Prayer)". This is the school of a group of the people of knowledge like Ibn Taymiyyah and others.
Second: Fabricated Hadiths or those with no basis, whose matter was hidden from some jurists, so they built upon them rulings that are from the core of innovations and introduced matters!
Third: Interpretations (Ijtihad) and preferences (Istihsan) issued by some jurists, especially the later ones, which they did not support with any legal evidence; rather, they presented them as if they were accepted matters until they became Sunnahs to be followed. It is not hidden from the one with insight into his religion that this is something not permissible to follow, for there is no legislation except what Allah the Exalted legislated. It is enough for the one who considers something good (Mustahsin), if he is a Mujtahid, that it be permissible for him alone to act upon what he deemed good and that Allah not hold him accountable for it. But for people to take that as Sharia and Sunnah, then no, and again no. How is it when some of them are contrary to the practical Sunnah, as will be alerted to, God willing?
Fourth: Customs and superstitions not indicated by the Law nor attested to by reason, even if some ignorant people act upon them and take them as a law for themselves, and they did not lack those who support them, even in some of that, among those who claim to be people of knowledge and dress in their garb.
Then let it be known that these innovations are not of one level in status; rather, they are of degrees. Some of them are Shirk and explicit Kufr as you will see, and some are less than that. But it must be known that the smallest innovation a man brings into the religion is

forbidden after it becomes clear that it is an innovation. There is nothing in innovations, as some imagine, that is only in the rank of Makruh (disliked). How can that be when the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) says: "Every innovation is misguidance, and every misguidance is in the Fire," meaning its doer. Imam Al-Shatibi, may Allah have mercy on him, verified this most completely in his great book "Al-I'tisam". Therefore, the matter of innovation is very dangerous, and most people are still heedless of it; only a group of the people of knowledge know that. Sufficient proof for you regarding the danger of innovation is his saying (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): "Indeed, Allah has blocked repentance from every person of innovation until he leaves his innovation." Narrated by Al-Tabarani and Al-Diya Al-Maqdisi in "Al-Ahadith Al-Mukhtara" and others with an authentic chain, and Al-Mundhiri classified it as Hasan (1).
I conclude this word with advice I present to the readers from a great Imam of the early Muslim scholars, Sheikh Al-Hasan bin Ali Al-Barbahari, from the companions of Imam Ahmad, may Allah have mercy on him, who died in the year "329". He said, may Allah the Exalted have mercy on him: "Beware of small introduced matters, for small innovations return until they become large. Likewise, every innovation introduced in this Umrah began as something small resembling the truth, so he who entered into it was deceived by that, then he could not get out of it. So it became great and became a religion that is practiced. So look, may Allah have mercy on you, at everyone whose speech you hear from the people of your time specifically; do not rush and do not enter into anything of it until you ask and look: Did anyone of the Companions of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) speak about it, or anyone of the scholars? If you find a trace from them, hold onto it, do not go beyond it for anything, and do not choose anything over it, lest you fall into the Fire. Know, may Allah have mercy on you, that the Islam of a servant is not complete until he is a follower, confirming

and submitting. So whoever claims that there remains anything of the matter of Islam that the Companions of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) did not suffice us in, he has lied against them. This is sufficient as division and impugning them; so he is an innovator, misguided, misguiding, introducing into Islam what is not in it."
I say: May Allah have mercy on Imam Malik when he said: "The latter part of this nation will not be rectified except by that which rectified its first part. What was not religion then is not religion today."
May Allah send blessings upon our Prophet who said: "I have not left anything that brings you closer to Allah except that I have commanded you with it, and I have not left anything that distances you from Allah and brings you closer to the Fire except that I have forbidden you from it."
Praise be to Allah by whose grace good deeds are completed.

Innovations Before Ihram
1- Abstaining from travel in the month of Safar and refraining from starting actions in it, such as marriage, consummation, etc.
2- Abstaining from travel during the waning of the moon (Muhaq) and when the moon is in Scorpio.
3- Refraining from cleaning the house and sweeping it after the traveler departs.
4- Praying two Rak'ahs when leaving for Hajj, reciting in the first after Al-Fatihah {Say, O disbelievers} and in the second "Al-Ikhlas". When finished, saying: "O Allah, with You I have spread out and to You I have turned..." and reciting Ayat al-Kursi, Surah Al-Ikhlas, Al-Mu'awwidhatayn, and other things mentioned in some fiqh books.
5- Praying four Rak'ahs.
6- The one intending Hajj reading, when leaving his house, the end of Surah "Al Imran", Ayat al-Kursi, {Indeed, We sent it down}, and "The Mother of the Book" (Al-Fatihah), claiming that in them is the fulfillment of worldly and Otherworldly needs.

text: Innovations of Muzdalifah: 95- I-da' (Hurrying) at the time of pushing on from Arafah to Muzdalifah. 96- Bathing for the overnight stay at Muzdalifah. 97- Deeming it recommended for the rider to dismount to enter Muzdalifah walking out of reverence for the Sanctuary. 98- Adhering to the supplication upon reaching Muzdalifah saying: O Allah, this is Muzdalifah, different tongues have gathered in it asking You for future needs... etc., as in 'Al-Ihya'. 99- Leaving the initiative to pray Maghrib immediately upon arriving in Muzdalifah and busying oneself instead with gathering pebbles. 100- Praying the Sunnah of Maghrib between the two prayers or combining it with the Sunnah of Isha and Witr after the two obligatory prayers, as Al-Ghazali says. 101- Increasing the lighting on the night of Sacrifice and at the Sacred Monument (Al-Mash'ar Al-Haram). 102- Staying awake (Ihya') this night [in worship]. 103- Stopping at Muzdalifah without spending the night. 104- Adhering to the supplication upon reaching the Sacred Monument saying: O Allah, by the right of the Sacred Monument, the Sacred House, the Corner, and the Station, convey the greeting and peace from us to the spirit of Muhammad, and enter us into the Abode of Peace, O Possessor of Majesty and Honor (1). 105- The saying of Al-Bajuri (318): It is Sunnah to take the pebbles to be thrown on the Day of Sacrifice from Muzdalifah, which are seven, and the rest for the Jamarat are taken from Wadi Muhassir.

Another said: He curls his index finger and places it on the joint of his thumb as if making the number ten. 112- Determining the standing position of the thrower: That there should be five cubits or more between him and the target. 113- Stoning the Jamarat with sandals and other things.

text: Innovations of Visiting in Medina Al-Munawwarah: Since it is from the Sunnah to travel to visit the Noble Prophetic Mosque and Al-Masjid Al-Aqsa—may Allah return it to the Muslims soon—due to the virtue and reward reported regarding that, and people usually visit them before Hajj or after it, and many of them commit numerous newly invented matters and innovations known to the scholars while doing so, I saw that to complete the benefit I should list what I have come across of them as a notification and warning, so I say: 132- Intending the grave of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, with the travel (1). 133- Sending petitions with pilgrims and visitors to the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and burdening them with conveying their peace to him.
foot_note: 1. 1 The Sunnah is to intend the Mosque, due to his saying, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him: 'Do not saddle the mounts [travel] except to three mosques...' the Hadith. When he arrives there and prays the greeting prayer, he visits his grave, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him. It must be known that traveling to visit his grave, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and others is one thing, and visiting without traveling [specifically for the grave] is another thing, contrary to what has become common among later people, including some doctors, of confusing the two and attributing to Sheikh Al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him, specifically, and the Salafis generally, that they deny the legitimacy of visiting the grave of the Messenger, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him; this is a clear fabrication. Refer to the details if you wish in our refutation of Dr. Al-Buti, which was published successively in serialized articles in the magazine 'Al-Tamaddun Al-Islamiyah', then issued in a special booklet titled 'Defense of the Prophetic Hadith...', and it has been reprinted by offset recently, praise be to Allah.

text: 134- Bathing before entering Medina Al-Munawwarah. 135- Saying when seeing the walls of Medina: O Allah, this is the sanctuary of Your Messenger, so make it a protection for me from the Fire and a security from punishment and bad reckoning. 136- Saying upon entering Medina: In the name of Allah and upon the religion of the Messenger of Allah: {And say, 'My Lord, cause me to enter a sound entrance and to exit a sound exit and grant me from Yourself a supporting authority'}. 137- Keeping the Prophetic grave inside his mosque. 138- Visiting his grave, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, before praying in his mosque. 139- Some of them facing the grave with utmost humility, placing the right hand over the left as one does in prayer, near it or far from it upon entering the mosque or leaving it. 140- Intending to face the grave during supplication. 141- Intending the grave to supplicate at it hoping for an answer. 142- Seeking Tawassul through him, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, to Allah in supplication. 143- Asking for intercession and other things from him. 144- The saying of Ibn Al-Hajj in 'Al-Madkhil' (1/159) that among the etiquette is: 'That he should not mention his needs and the forgiveness of his sins with his tongue when visiting his grave, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, because he is more knowledgeable than him about his needs and interests'!! 145- His saying also (1/264): 'There is no difference between his death, peace be upon him, and his life regarding his witnessing of his Ummah and his knowledge of their states, intentions, regrets, and thoughts'!! 146- Placing their hand for blessing on the grate of his grave's chamber, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and swearing

3. 3 This, besides being an innovation and exaggeration in religion, and contrary to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: 'Do not take my grave as a place of festivity (Eid), and send blessings upon me wherever you are, for your blessings reach me,' is a cause for neglecting many Sunnahs and abundant virtues, namely the Dhikrs and Wirds after the Salutation (Salam), for they abandon them and hasten to this innovation. May Allah have mercy on the one who said: No innovation is introduced except that a Sunnah dies.

text: 154- Seeking blessings from what falls with the rain of pieces of green paint from the dome of the Prophetic grave!. 155- Seeking nearness by eating Sayhani dates in the Noble Rawdah between the Minbar and the Grave. 156- Cutting off their hair and throwing it into the large lamp near the Prophetic soil. 157- Some wiping their hands on the two brass palm trees placed in the mosque west of the Minbar (1). 158- Many adhering to praying in the old mosque and turning away from the first rows which are in the expansion of Umar and others. 159- Visitors of Medina adhering to staying there for a week so they can pray forty prayers in the Prophetic Mosque so that exemption from hypocrisy and exemption from the Fire are written for them (2). 160- Intending any of the mosques and shrines in Medina and around it after the Mosque of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, except Masjid Quba. 161- Those known as 'guides' (Muzawwirin) instructing groups of pilgrims with certain Dhikrs and Wirds at the Chamber or far from it with loud voices, and these people repeating what they were instructed with even louder voices. 162- Visiting Al-Baqi' every day and praying in the Mosque of Fatimah, may Allah be pleased with her. 163- Allocating Thursday for visiting the martyrs of Uhud. 164- Tying rags to the window overlooking the ground of the martyrs. 165- Seeking blessings by bathing in the pool that used to be beside their graves. 166- Exiting the Prophetic Mosque walking backwards when saying farewell.

1. 1 There is absolutely no benefit from these two palm trees; they were placed for decoration and to tempt people, and they have been removed recently, praise be to Allah. 
2. 2 The hadith reported regarding that is weak and cannot be used as a proof. I have explained its defect in 'Al-Silsilah Al-Da'ifah 364'. It is not permissible to act upon it because it is legislation, especially since some pilgrims might feel guilty about it, as I have known myself, thinking that what is reported in it is established and authentic, and they might miss some prayers therein and fall into hardship, while Allah has relieved them of it. Some virtuous people have leaned towards strengthening the mentioned hadith relying on Ibn Hibban's authentication of one of its unknown narrators. This authentication is not relied upon by the scholars of Jarh and Ta'dil (Criticism and Praise), including the referenced virtuous person himself, as he stated in his refutation of Sheikh Al-Ghumari in the magazine 'Al-Jami'ah Al-Salafiyyah' published in India. Refer for this to the book of Sheikh Abdul Aziz Al-Rabi'an in refutation of him, for he did well in it and benefited, and explained the weakness of the strengthening view he adopted and his contradiction in that.

text: Innovations of Bayt Al-Maqdis (Jerusalem): 167- Intending to visit Bayt Al-Maqdis along with Hajj and their saying: May Allah sanctify your Hajj. 168- Circumambulating the Dome of the Rock imitating the circumambulation of the Kaaba. 169- Venerating the Rock with any type of veneration such as wiping on it, kissing it, driving sheep to it to slaughter them there, performing Ta'reef (standing as in Arafah) by it on the evening of Arafah, building upon it, and other things. 170- His claim that there is a footprint of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, on the Rock, and a trace of his turban, and some of them think it is the place of the foot of the Lord, Glory be to Him and Exalted. 171- Visiting the place they claim is the cradle of Jesus, peace be upon him. 172- Their claim that the Sirat (Bridge) and the Balance (Mizan) are there, and that the wall that will be struck between Paradise and Hell is that wall built east of the Mosque. 174- Venerating the chain or its place. 175- Praying at the grave of Abraham the Friend (Al-Khalil), peace be upon him.
